Award.AwardTitle: Development of New Chemical Triggers for Spin-State Switching
Award.AbstractNarration:
In this project funded by the Chemical Structure, Dynamics and Mechanism B program of the Chemistry Division, Professor Matthew Shores of Colorado State University is investigating new transition metal complexes whose physical (spin) properties are linked to the presence of guest molecules. This research aims to support the development of (1) inexpensive colorimetric sensors for colorless anions of biological (phosphates, chloride) and/or environmental (nitrate, cyanide, perchlorate) significance; and (2) new magnetic resonance contrast agents that reversibly turn on when interacting with target molecules. The project will support magnetic collaborations between the PI and 7 other research groups who do not have ready access to sensitive magnetic measurement techniques and data interpretation experience. Potential societal benefits include the discovery of new anion sensors and turn-on magnetic resonance contrast agents as well as a cross disciplinary training ground for graduate and undergraduate students.

The project focuses on controlling the spin-states of first-row transition metal complexes via secondary, non-covalent interactions such as hydrogen bonding. The aim is to switch reliably between low- and high-spin states, in both directions, with a variety of chemical triggers. The research involves design and synthesis of new Fe(II), Fe(III) and Co(II) complexes, solid state and solution phase structural and magnetic characterization, and guest binding studies monitored by UV-Visible and NMR spectroscopies. Toward increasing environmental stability of promising molecules, cellulose-based hybrid materials are targeted where anion-dependent spin-state switching is expected to persist at the surface-solution interface. Incorporating anion-dependent spin-state switching properties to paper-based devices generates an opportunity for new sensors, easy to use, with wide portability and easy (visual) detection, suitable for wide distribution to citizens to estimate exposure to anionic pollutants.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In this project funded by the Chemical Structure, Dynamics and Mechanism Program of the Chemistry Division, Matthew Shores’ chemistry research group at Colorado State University combined chemical synthesis and measurement techniques to investigate new transition metal complexes whose physical (spin) properties are linked to the presence of guest molecules, toward improved understanding of molecular-scale switching events. Such switches could have diverse applications in memory, display and sensor devices. The overarching aim in the current project was to design and study systems where the small energies involved in controlling spin-states through non-covalent interactions can be controlled. The expectation was that the project would improve our understanding of switching between low- and high-spin states, in both directions, with a variety of chemical triggers.

The research group developed a family of electronically- and sterically-tunable ligands, prepared a wide range of iron, cobalt and nickel complexes, and carefully studied their magnetic properties in several environments – in the solid state, dissolved in several solvents, at multiple temperatures, with and without added salts. The group was able to assess and control spin-crossover (SC) behavior in iron complexes, and probed single-molecule magnetism (SMM) behavior in nickel and cobalt complexes.

The key results of the project are summarized here. First, anion-triggered spin-state switching was developed further in Fe(II) complexes. What is new here is that the guest induced a low-spin to high-spin switching event – the energy barrier is much higher for this switch than going in the opposite direction. The electronic and steric impacts of ligand substituents on Fe(II) spin-crossover properties were studied in detail, and resulted in the development of new computational protocols and functionals for accurate modeling of small energies relevant to spin-crossover. The switching observed in the Fe(II) imino/amino-pyridine complex is a proof-of-concept result that may have significant impact in the area of smart magnetic resonance contrast agents, where specific host-guest interactions could turn on the paramagnetism required for magnetic resonance contrast.  

Second, SMM behavior was observed and tuned in several Co(II) complex families. (a) A series of 4-, 5- and 5-coordinate cobalt terpyridine complexes were prepared and studied. (b) Cation binding was observed in a Co(II) podand complex. (c) Magnetic anisotropy in a Co(II) podand complex was found to depend on the charge-balancing anion present in the salt. The ability to turn on (or off) anisotropy in metal complexes could be used in the future for sensing or imaging applications via electron paramagnetic resonance techniques.

Third, the group found that Ni(III) complexes with simple ligands could behave as single-molecule magnets. This is an interesting discovery because Ni(III) in these complexes is in the low spin state, and has only 1 unpaired electron. Such species should not be SMMs, nevertheless slow relaxation of magnetization was observed. The discovery of SMM behavior in a low spin Ni(III) complex adds to a short list of S=1/2 molecular magnets. The family of complexes uncovered in this work allow (in principle) separation of inter- and intramolecular effects on SMM behavior. This may be applicable to understanding and optimizing molecular magnets for quantum computing qubits.

Overall, the group showed that the anion-binding iminopyridine ligands can also bind cations, demonstrating ligand flexibility. It generated new examples of SMMs containing one paramagnetic spin center. It uncovered conditions where magnetic anisotropy can be switched by small outer-sphere interactions. The group now understands better the impact of anion binding on magnetostructural correlations in SMMs.

This project supported research efforts for 7 graduate students, 1 postdoc, and 1 undergraduate. The junior researchers were trained in air- and moisture-sensitive inorganic synthesis techniques, X-ray crystallography, spectroscopic characterization methods, and magnetometry. The PI and research group also contributed to the mentoring and professional development activities of the long-running CSU Chemistry REU program. The results from this project were disseminated in several papers (with several manuscripts in preparation) and through student and PI presentations at multiple seminars, including four international conferences. Two PhD degrees and two MS degrees were awarded for work completed in this project. The project strengthened an ongoing theory-experiment collaboration at CSU, and research results generated in the project were incorporated into (under)graduate chemistry course materials.

Magnetic property measurements are important for understanding electronic structure in metal-containing compounds, but many researchers don’t have easy access to the required facilities. As part of the broadening and outreach activities associated with this project, nine collaborations with research groups across the country (Georgia Tech, Purdue, Auburn, Rochester, Boston University, UC Irvine (2x), SUNY Buffalo, Missouri) were established and/or maintained. Magnetic measurements performed by the Shores group contributed to the understanding of electronic structure in a wide range of inorganic and molecular materials provided by the collaborators. In turn, the researchers in the Shores group gained valuable experience with a diverse set of paramagnetic materials, and contributed to new examples of spin-crossover, single-molecule magnetism, and single-chain magnetism.
